author: HCAndersen
text: FAR in the interior of the country lay an old baronial hall, and in it lived an old proprietor, who had two sons, which two young men thought themselves too clever by half.

author: HCAndersen
text: They wanted to go out and woo the King's daughter; for the maiden in question had publicly announced that she would choose for her husband that youth who could arrange his words best.

author: HCAndersen
text: So these two geniuses prepared themselves a full week for the wooing- this was the longest time that could be granted them; but it was enough, for they had had much preparatory information, and everybody knows how useful that is.

author: HCAndersen
text: One of them knew the whole Latin dictionary by heart, and three whole years of the daily paper of the little town into the bargain, and so well, indeed, that he could repeat it all either backwards or forwards, just as he chose.

author: HCAndersen
text: The other was deeply read in the corporation laws, and knew by heart what every corporation ought to know; and accordingly he thought he could talk of affairs of state, and put his spoke in the wheel in the council.

author: HCAndersen
text: And he knew one thing more: he could embroider suspenders with roses and other flowers, and with arabesques, for he was a tasty, light-fingered fellow.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall win the Princess!"

author: HCAndersen
text: So cried both of them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Therefore their old papa gave to each of them a handsome horse.

author: HCAndersen
text: The youth who knew the dictionary and newspaper by heart had a black horse, and he who knew all about the corporation laws received a milk-white steed.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they rubbed the corners of their mouths with fish-oil, so that they might become very smooth and glib.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the servants stood below in the courtyard, and looked on while they mounted their horses; and just by chance the third son came up.

author: HCAndersen
text: For the proprietor had really three sons, though nobody counted the third with his brothers, because he was not so learned as they, and indeed he was generally known as "Jack the Dullard."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hallo!" said Jack the Dullard, "where are you going?

author: HCAndersen
text: I declare you have put on your Sunday clothes!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "We're going to the King's court, as suitors to the King's daughter.

author: HCAndersen
text: Don't you know the announcement that has been made all through the country?"

author: HCAndersen
text: And they told him all about it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "My word!

author: HCAndersen
text: I'll be in it too!" cried Jack the Dullard; and his two brothers burst out laughing at him, and rode away.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Father, dear," said Jack, "I must have a horse too.

author: HCAndersen
text: I do feel so desperately inclined to marry!

author: HCAndersen
text: If she accepts me, she accepts me; and if she won't have me, I'll have her; but she shall be mine!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't talk nonsense," replied the old gentleman.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You shall have no horse from me.

author: HCAndersen
text: You don't know how to speak- you can't arrange your words.

author: HCAndersen
text: Your brothers are very different fellows from you."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well," quoth Jack the Dullard, "If I can't have a horse, I'll take the Billy-goat, who belongs to me, and he can carry me very well!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And so said, so done.

author: HCAndersen
text: He mounted the Billy-goat, pressed his heels into its sides, and galloped down the high street like a hurricane.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hei, houp! that was a ride!

author: HCAndersen
text: Here I come!" shouted Jack the Dullard, and he sang till his voice echoed far and wide.

author: HCAndersen
text: But his brothers rode slowly on in advance of him.

author: HCAndersen
text: They spoke not a word, for they were thinking about the fine extempore speeches they would have to bring out, and these had to be cleverly prepared beforehand.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hallo!" shouted Jack the Dullard.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here am I!

author: HCAndersen
text: Look what I have found on the high road."

author: HCAndersen
text: And he showed them what it was, and it was a dead crow.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Dullard!" exclaimed the brothers, "what are you going to do with that?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "With the crow? why, I am going to give it to the Princess."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, do so," said they; and they laughed, and rode on.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hallo, here I am again! just see what I have found now: you don't find that on the high road every day!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And the brothers turned round to see what he could have found now.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Dullard!" they cried, "that is only an old wooden shoe, and the upper part is missing into the bargain; are you going to give that also to the Princess?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Most certainly I shall," replied Jack the Dullard; and again the brothers laughed and rode on, and thus they got far in advance of him; but- "Hallo- hop rara!" and there was Jack the Dullard again.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is getting better and better," he cried.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hurrah! it is quite famous."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why, what have you found this time?" inquired the brothers.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh," said Jack the Dullard, "I can hardly tell you.

author: HCAndersen
text: How glad the Princess will be!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Bah!" said the brothers; "that is nothing but clay out of the ditch."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, certainly it is," said Jack the Dullard; "and clay of the finest sort.

author: HCAndersen
text: See, it is so wet, it runs through one's fingers."

author: HCAndersen
text: And he filled his pocket with the clay.

author: HCAndersen
text: But his brothers galloped on till the sparks flew, and consequently they arrived a full hour earlier at the town gate than could Jack.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now at the gate each suitor was provided with a number, and all were placed in rows immediately on their arrival, six in each row, and so closely packed together that they could not move their arms; and that was a prudent arrangement, for they would certainly have come to blows, had they been able, merely because one of them stood before the other.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the inhabitants of the country round about stood in great crowds around the castle, almost under the very windows, to see the Princess receive the suitors; and as each stepped into the hall, his power of speech seemed to desert him, like the light of a candle that is blown out.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the Princess would say, "He is of no use!

author: HCAndersen
text: Away with him out of the hall!"

author: HCAndersen
text: At last the turn came for that brother who knew the dictionary by heart; but he did not know it now; he had absolutely forgotten it altogether; and the boards seemed to re-echo with his footsteps, and the ceiling of the hall was made of looking-glass, so that he saw himself standing on his head; and at the window stood three clerks and a head clerk, and every one of them was writing down every single word that was uttered, so that it might be printed in the newspapers, and sold for a penny at the street corners.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was a terrible ordeal, and they had, moreover, made such a fire in the stove, that the room seemed quite red hot.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is dreadfully hot here!" observed the first brother.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes," replied the Princess, "my father is going to roast young pullets today."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Baa!" there he stood like a baa-lamb.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had not been prepared for a speech of this kind, and had not a word to say, though he intended to say something witty.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Baa!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "He is of no use!" said the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Away with him!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And he was obliged to go accordingly.

author: HCAndersen
text: And now the second brother came in.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is terribly warm here!" he observed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, we're roasting pullets to-day," replied the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What- what were you- were you pleased to ob-" stammered he- and all the clerks wrote down, "pleased to ob-" "He is of no use!" said the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Away with him!"

author: HCAndersen
text: Now came the turn of Jack the Dullard.

author: HCAndersen
text: He rode into the hall on his goat.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, it's most abominably hot here."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, because I'm roasting young pullets," replied the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, that's lucky!" exclaimed Jack the Dullard, "for I suppose you'll let me roast my crow at the same time?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "With the greatest pleasure," said the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But have you anything you can roast it in? for I have neither pot nor pan."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Certainly I have!" said Jack.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here's a cooking utensil with a tin handle."

author: HCAndersen
text: And he brought out the old wooden shoe, and put the crow into it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, that is a famous dish!" said the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But what shall we do for sauce?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, I have that in my pocket," said Jack; "I have so much of it that I can afford to throw some away;" and he poured some of the clay out of his pocket.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I like that!" said the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You can give an answer, and you have something to say for yourself, and so you shall be my husband.

author: HCAndersen
text: But are you aware that every word we speak is being taken down, and will be published in the paper to-morrow?

author: HCAndersen
text: Look yonder, and you will see in every window three clerks and a head clerk; and the old head clerk is the worst of all, for he can't understand anything."

author: HCAndersen
text: But she only said this to frighten Jack the Dullard; and the clerks gave a great crow of delight, and each one spurted a blot out of his pen on to the floor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, those are the gentlemen, are they?" said Jack; "then I will give the best I have to the head clerk."

author: HCAndersen
text: And he turned out his pockets, and flung the wet clay full in the head clerk's face.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That was very cleverly done," observed the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I could not have done that; but I shall learn in time."

author: HCAndersen
text: And accordingly Jack the Dullard was made a king, and received a crown and a wife, and sat upon a throne.

author: HCAndersen
text: And this report we have wet from the press of the head clerk and the corporation of printers- but they are not to be depended upon in the least.
